1. INTRODUCTION
The tide of research on two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials has turned when Geim and Novoselov acquired the 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics for isolating and stabilizing a single-layered graphene firstly in 2004 [1]. Over the past years, the most wide research in twodimensional materials primarily focused on graphene based on its preeminent mechanical, electronic, optical, magnetic and thermal qualities [2-10] has been presented. In addition, the saturable absorption property of BP and BPQDs had been verified which endows them with high performance for ultrafast photonics and especially provides a practical solution to solve the optical damage problem of BP by assembling with waveguide structures such as microfiber [29, 30]. Very recently, BPbased materials have also aroused interest in the field of biomedicine. In this review article, we mainly discuss the latest biomedical applications of BP and BPQDs, moreover, the synthesis and surface functionalization of BP and BPQDs are also summarized. It is believed that such a work could help non-experts who are interested in this field to know the preliminary progresses, future prospects, as well as the state-of-art unsolved critical issues of using BP-based material for theranostic applications.

sections.heading: 2. FABRICATION OF BP AND BPQDs
sections.text: Reliable production of BP nanomaterials with fewlayers is fundamental to obtain their fascinating applications not only in electronics and photoelectric devices, but also in biomedicine. Here, we review and comment on several current methods to prepare BP nanosheets and BPQDs.

sections.heading: 2.1. Top-Down Methods
sections.text:
The isolation of single-layer graphene from bulk graphite by mechanical exfoliation opened up exciting
new vistas of 2D materials [1, 31]. This method has been proved to effectively cleave bulk BP down to the single-layer or mono-layer ones owing to P atoms are connected by intra-layer P-P bonding and weak interlayer van der waals force, as previously mentioned. BP sheets peeled from their parent bulk crystal, which not only possess large size and complete structure, but own high purity and cleanliness, that are firstrank for fundamental characterization, and for fabrication of individual devices. However, the process involved in this method is not applicable for mass production and lack of systematic control of flake thickness and size, hence, is inappropriate to use in the laboratory or industrial applications [32, 33]. It is well known that the number of layers and thickness are the key parameters that define the electronic, optical and thermal properties of 2D nanomaterials. Fortunately, some improved fabrication methods have been found. One example is the plasma-assisted process, as was also used for graphene and MoS2 [34, 35]. Last few years, Lu et al. [36] demonstrated a promising experimental approach to fabricate monolayer phosphorene by mechanical cleavage and a subsequent Ar+ plasma thinning process. Few-layer BP sample obtained by mechanical exfoliation on the SiO2/Si substrate was eventually performed to thin down the thin phosphorene sheets for 20 s at room temperature by Ar+ plasma with a power of 30 W and a pressure of 30 Pa. In addition, conventional mechanical exfoliation with adhesive tape and modified mechanical exfoliation were also introduced to yield few-layer BP and numerous approaches were adopted to protect BP from degradation and oxidation once it is mechanically exfoliated [37].
Over the past decades, liquid-phase exfoliation has been successfully applied for the fabrication of TMDCs family and graphene, which have shown good performances not only in devices, but in the field of biomedicine [38-44]. Recently, liquid-phase preparation techniques are also explored to obtain larger quantities of exfoliated phosphorene nanosheets, which may be the most suitable for laboratory level demonstrations (Fig. 2a). Brent et al. [45] firstly reported the liquid exfoliation of BP in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) to produce few-layer phosphorene. The as-prepared BPnanosheets exhibit typical nanoflake morphology with monodispersity and irregular shape, and display a height of about 2.0 nm (Fig. 2b-d) [46]. Moreover, following researchers kept trying to prepare large-scale, stable, highly concentrated solution dispersions of BP atomic layers via exfoliating in conventional organic solvents such as alcohols, chloroorganic solvents, ketones, cyclic or aliphatic pyrrolidones, N-alkylsubstituted amides, and organosulfur compounds), combining probe sonication and bath sonication, grinding and shearing [32, 33, 47-50]. However, some intrinsic drawbacks including relatively low concentrations and the fabrication in environmentally unfriendly organic solvents severely inhibit their clinical applica-
tions. Another promising alternative method that is the ionic liquids (ILs)-exfoliation involves grinding with ILs followed by ice-bath sonication processes in ILs [51]. Compared to traditional organic solvents, ILs possess many excellent properties such as high thermal stability, high viscosity, nontoxicity, versatile solubility and solvent recyclability, enable a high solubility of BP atomic layers in liquid phase (up to 0.95 mg/mL) with good storage stability.

sections.heading: 2.2. Bottom-Up Methods
sections.text:
Mechanical exfoliation and liquid exfoliation methods with multiple organic solvent have shown the most progress so far, nevertheless, large area single/fewlayer phosphorene is still unreachable. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method has been developed for large-scale device fabrication of 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene and TMDCs [52-55]. Unfortunately, this strategy for the synthesis of black phosphorene is challenged because of its chemically active surface that is fragile when exposed to air, as well as the absence of a suitable substrate for its CVD growth. Joshua et al. [56] demonstrated the synthesis of 2D BP with average areas >3 μm2 from red phosphorus directly on a silicon substrate in situ chemical vapor deposition type approach, this accomplishment provided good examples for possible phosphorene chemical growth. Along with the concerted efforts from the materials and chemistry communities, the development and implementation of large-area, few-layer BP on insulating substrates by chemical vapor deposition will be more promising.

Benefiting from tremendous efforts have been made, the large quantities of BP nanoparticles can be
produced. However, except from the biodegradation, BP nanosheets and BPQDs will aggregates in physiological buffers and basal medium in the presence of salts caused by the charge screening effect. Fortunately, appropriate surface modification could improve the biocompatibility of the above nanomaterials and control their degradable behaviors in physiological solutions. Furthermore, by establishing the efficient surface engineering methodologies we can enhance the photothermal-conversion efficiency, the targeting efficiency especially for cancer therapy of nanomaterials, as well as endow them with highly enriched functionalities. Regrettably, compared with graphene oxide, the efficient surface engineering methodologies of BPbased nanoparticles are rather plain because they do not possess many chemically reactive groups such as carboxylic acid group as well as epoxy and hydroxyl groups [84-86]. In addition to synthetic polymers coated by biocompatible polymer via simple electrostatic interaction, two dimensional nanomaterials can also serve as a support material with which to anchor semiconductor particles to enhance photocatalytic performance and the efficiency of energy conversion [96, 97]. sections.heading: 5. BLACK PHOSPHORUS-BASED NANOMATERIALS FOR DRUG DELIVERY
sections.text:
In the past few years, nanomaterial-based drug delivery platforms have been widely researched for the treatment of cancer [102-104]. Single-layered BP nanoparticles possess relatively large surface area which can delivery other agents into cancer cells. Very recently, Mei group reported that the PEGylated BP NSs can load doxorubicin (DOX) (Fig. 7) for chemotherapy, the fluorescent dye Cy7-NH2 for NIR imaging and the loading of DOX was tested to be ≈108% [105]. Moreover, they further investigated the drug-release behavior and the date showed that ≈33.4% of DOX was released from the drug delivery platforms at pH 5.0 after 24 h. Beyond that, in order to endow nano-drug the ability of targeting a specific kind of cells, they also designed a multi-functionalized BP that contains Folic acid (FA) which could selectively target folate receptor over-expressing cells. In another relevant work, Chen et al. utilized the BP as a DOX carrier, and realized the photothermal enhanced and pH value controlled DOX released [80]. Although, few studies on BP-based nanostructures for drug delivery have been reported, we confirmed that BP-based nanomaterials with suitable surface modification will be widely used for various drug and gene delivery.

sections.heading: 6. BLACK PHOSPHORUS-BASED NANOMATERIALS FOR PHOTO THERAPIES FOR CANCER
sections.text: Photo therapies, mainly including photothermal therapy (PTT) and photodynamic therapy (PDT) can kill cancer cells under specific light irradiation. Owing to photo therapy nanoagents could take advantage of the optical window of tissue (600-1000 nm) and target cancers due to the enhanced permeability and retention effect, the cancer cells would be destructed selectively without damage to normal tissues and organs. Over the past few decades, photo therapies have shown outstanding treatment effect for diverse cancers.

sections.heading: 6.1. Photothermal Therapy
sections.text:
PTT utilizing optical-absorbing agents that can generate hyperthermia under light irradiation to kill tumor cells have been widely developed. In the past few years, numerous NIR light-responsive nanomaterials including gold nanostructures, carbon nanoparticles, CuS nanoparticles, TiO2 and even organic nanoparticles have been demonstrated for cancer photothermal therapy [106-111]. Utilizing their inherent broad absorption across the ultraviolet and infrared regions and splendid photothermal conversion efficiency, BP-based nano-
particles with suitable functionalization have also been used as photothermal agents for in vivo cancer treatment with appealing therapeutic consequences [79, 80]. In the work conducted by Sun et al., the PEGylated BPQDs exhibited concentration-dependent photothermal effect under an 808 nm laser, also showed brilliant photothermal stability as illustrated in five on/off circle tests [61] (Fig. 8a and b). For in vitro photothermal analysis, C6 and MCF7 cells were almost completely killed with only 50 ppm of the PEG-modified BPQDs exposed to the 808 nm laser at a power density of 1.0 W/cm2 for 10 min (Fig. 8c and d). In another work, Li group further assessed the photothermal effect of BPbased materials against tumor growth in vivo [111]. The data showed that tumor growth of the mice treated with both PEGylated BP nanoparticles and laser irradiation (2.0 W/cm2, 5min) was distinctly inhibited (Fig. 9a and b). In addition, the mice in the treated group were tumor-free after treatment and survived for over 42 days showing an effective photothermal of BP nanosheets for cancer therapy (Fig. 9c). These results demonstrate the promise of using BP-based nanoparticles with suitable functionalization for excellent efficacy photothermal cancer therapy.

sections.heading: 6.2. Photodynamic Therapy
sections.text:
Different from PTT, PDT uses suitable light irradiation to activate photosensitizers to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill cancer cells [112]. In the past years, PDT drugs including porphyrins and porphyrin derivatives have attracted tremendous interest ascribed to their excellent cellular affinity and low toxicity [113, 114]. BP nanosheets also exhibit distinguished photodynamic performance so that BP-based nanomaterials could be used as effectual PDT agents. To the best of our knowledge, Wang et al. firstly reported the study of exfoliated black phosphorus nanosheets to be effective photosensitizers for the generation of singlet oxygen and demonstrated their attractive applications in photodynamic therapy against cancer cells in vivo and in vitro [46]. In a later work, Lv and co-workers [115] designed a novel multifunctional composite by integrating NaGd-F4:Yb, Er@Yb@ Nd@Yb upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) and black phosphorus sheets (BPs) via electrostatic interaction. After co-incubation of UCNP-BPs composites with HeLa cells followed by laser irradiation with wavelengths of 650 nm and 808 nm, the viability of HeLa cells was significantly decreased and the corresponding IC50 values were determined to be 57.1 and
42.7μg mL−1, respectively (Fig. 10a and b). In the in vivo experiments, the tumor growth of the mice after laser irradiation with wavelengths of 650 nm and 808 nm was inhibited compared to compared to other control groups (Fig. 10c and d) showing the apparent tumor inhibition effect. It is uncovered that the mice did not lose body weight during the treatment indicating that UCNPs−BPs may have no conspicuous side effect to normal tissues (Fig. 10e).

sections.heading: 8. BLACK PHOSPHORUS-BASED NANOMATERIALS FOR BIOSENSING SYSTEMS
sections.text:
Layered and 2D materials have been successfully used in bio-sensing applications [120-122]. Recently, Yan et al. [50] synthesized a non-enzymatic H2O2 sensor based on few-layer BP to utilize BP degradation under ambient conditions. In that study, they firstly demonstrated supercritical CO2-assisted rapid synthesis of few-layer BP and achieved more accurate H2O2 determination than the general detection. Beyond that, Carmen and co-workers [119] utilized black phosphorus nanoparticles as electro-catalytic tags in a competitive immunoassay for rabbit immunoglobulin G (IgG) detection (Fig. 14). In that work, the layered black phosphorus micro-particles were downsized with bipolar electrodes in order to enhance electro-catalytic activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction. As far as we know, this is the first time that BP nanoparticles were used as a label for protein detection in a competitive immunoassay through hydrogen evolution reaction. CONCLUSION AND PERSPECTIVES
As a rising 2D material, BP has generated considerable excitement in biomedical applications due to numerous unique physical and chemical characteristics as described below: (i) high biocompatibility with very relatively lower toxicity; (ii) large surface area with high drug-loading efficiency; (iii) high NIR absorbance and effective photothermal conversion efficiency enlightening the encouraging PTT application; (iv) the capability to generate massive ROS enabling high-performance photodynamic cancer therapy. (v) intrinsic optical contrast characteristics that have been applied for fluorescence and PA bio-imaging. Moreover, a variety of modification methods have been developed to functionalize BP-based materials to endow them with sundry functionalities. Diverse biomolecules such as siRNA, DNA can also be loaded onto the surface of functionalized BP for gene transfection. The combination of these exceptional properties makes BP outstanding among the diverse nanoparticles with great promise for theranostic applications.
For further biomedical applications of BP, the most important challenge to conquer is the degradability in aqueous solution. What's worse is that the unstable structure will cause poor photothermal effect and storage difficulty. Although several suitable surface modifications to restrain the degradability have been carried out, we still need to explore more valid method to fabricate BP-based nanoparticles for long bloodcirculation, targeted transport and enhanced tumor accumulation. In addition, the absence of chemical synthesis to produce large scales makes it expensive compared with many other inorganic nanomaterials. As we all know, for biomedical applications of 2D nanomaterials, the highly significant thing is how to synthesize ultrathin nanosheets with uniform sheet size. Nevertheless, the morphology and size distribution of ultrathin BP nanosheets prepared by the mechanical exfoliation strategy are not satisfactorily uniform. On the other hand, the biodegradation process, rate and mechanism, the long-term biosafety evaluation of BP-based materials in biological systems are still not very clear. However, we highly believe that with the joint effort of researchers in various fields, the black phosphorus as an emerging two-dimensional nano-material will play a critical role in the field of theranostic applications.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.2174/0929867324666170920152529 Abstract: Ascribe to the unique two-dimensional planar nanostructure with exceptional physical and chemical properties, black phosphorous (BP) as the emerging inorganic twodimensional nanomaterial with high biocompatibility and degradability has been becoming one of the most promising materials of great potentials in biomedicine. The exfoliated BP sheets possess ultra-high surface area available for valid bio-conjugation and molecular loading for chemotherapy. Utilizing the intrinsic near-infrared optical absorbance, BPbased photothermal therapy in vivo, photodynamic therapy and biomedical imaging has been realized, achieving unprecedented anti-tumor therapeutic efficacy in animal experiments. Additionally, the BP nanosheets can strongly react with oxygen and water, and finally degrade to non-toxic phosphate and phosphonate in the aqueous solution. This manuscript aimed to summarize the preliminary progresses on theranostic application of BP and its derivatives black phosphorus quantum dots (BPQDs), and discussed the prospects and the state-of-art unsolved critical issues of using BP-based material for theranostic applications.
